I found this 'source-tag' option in the bdbfrontier, but I am using=

AdaptiveRevisitFrontier, the source-tage option seems to be missing on
thi=
s frontier, or am I missing something?


--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups=
.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@...> wrote:
>
> The 'source-tag' is inherited by =
each discovered URI. So when it is set 
> to be the seed URI, that seed URI=
 appears on all subsequent URIs. The 
> immediate-predecessor URI is availa=
ble as the 'via' URI, which also 
> appears in the crawl.log.
> 
> For exam=
ple, starting with...
> 
> seed:
>   uri: http://www.example.com
>   hops-p=
ath: (none)
>   via: (none)
>   source-tag: http://www.example.com
> 
> ...=
you might then discover an clickable outlink (an 'N' hop) in an <A> 
> HREF=
 attribute...
> 
> first discovered URI:
>   uri: http://www.example.com/su=
bsection
>   hops-path: N
>   via: http://www.example.com
>   source-tag: h=
ttp://www.example.com
> 
> ...and then discover an inline image URI (an 'E'=
 hop) in an <IMG> SRC 
> attribute...
> 
> second discovered URI:
>   uri: =
http://www.example.com/images/header.gif
>   hops-path: NE
>   via: http://=
www.example.com/subsection
>   source-tag: http://www.example.com
> 
> So y=
ou can construct the graph *as the crawler followed it* from the 
> crawl.l=
og, but you can also read the origin-seed and 
> immediate-predecessor URIs=
 from each line.
> 
> - Gordon @ IA
> 
> alihoaliho wrote:
> > is the 'sour=
ce' just the parent page of which the url was extracted
> > from? So to get=
 all the way to the originate seed, i need to construct
> > a graph and fol=
low the path to the root?
> > 
> > --- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, =
Gordon Mohr <gojomo@> wrote:
> >> If you set the 'source-tag-seeds' setting=
 of your Frontier to
'true', 
> >> each seed URI will be tagged with itself=
, and then each URI
discovered 
> >> from those seeds will inherit this sam=
e source seed. This source tag 
> >> will appear in the second-to-last fiel=
d of the crawl.log.
> >>
> >> So, you'll be able to see from the crawl.log =
the seed from which any
> > URI 
> >> was discovered.
> >>
> >> Note that i=
t's not guaranteed to be the seed from which the shortest 
> >> path to the=
 URI can be found -- the crawler sometimes follows
> > longer-hop 
> >> pat=
hs more quickly than shorter-hop paths, and the source tag
will be 
> >> th=
e seed from which the URi was actually discovered.
> >>
> >> (The above is =
true for 1.14.1; it looks like a bug in 2.0.1 is 
> >> preventing the sourc=
e tag from appearing in the crawl.log.)
> >>
> >> - Gordon @ IA
> >>
> >> a=
